PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Harry Jenkins) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on behalf of the Committee of Members' Interests, I present a special report from the Committee and I seek leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I must congratulate you on the fact that today, for the first time, I was present for prayers-they were my maiden prayers.
—I am sure it was not my persuasion.

—Mr Speaker, you do it well. The special report which I have just presented has been necessitated by the late establishment of the Committee of Members' Interests and, as a consequence, its inability to determine the form of annual return to be used by members in providing statements of their registrable interests. Nominations of all members to the Committee were not received until yesterday and the House agreed to the appointment of members to the Committee yesterday afternoon. The Committee met shortly afterwards but clearly it was quite impossible for it to determine the form of the annual return in the time available to it yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members will recall that on the morning of 9 October 1984 the House adopted resolutions requiring, among other matters, that members provide statements of certain registrable interests within 28 days of making an oath or affirmation at the commencement of this Parliament. The statements were to be provided in a form to be determined by the Committee of Members' Interests. In the absence of an approved form, it has not been possible for any member of the House in the present Parliament to comply with the requirement as the period of 28 days expired yesterday.

The Committee recommends in its report that, in the case of members of the House of Representatives of the Thirty-fourth Parliament who made and subscribed an oath or affirmation on 21 February 1985, a further period, namely 28 days from the day of issue of the forms of annual return by the Registrar of Members' Interests, be granted, within which they will be required to provide a statement of registrable interests to the Registrar of Members' Interests in accordance with the resolutions adopted by the House on the morning of 9 October 1984. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That-

(a) in the case of Members of the House of Representatives of the 34th Parliament who made and subscribed an oath or affirmation on 21 February 1985, a further period of 28 days from the day of issue of the forms of annual return by the Registrar of Members' Interests be granted within which they will be required to provide a statement of registrable interests to the Registrar of Members' Interests in accordance with the resolutions adopted by the House on 9 October 1984 a.m., and
(b) in all other respects, the resolution adopted by the House on 9 October 1984 a.m. relating to the registration and declaration of interests continue in force.

It is unfortunate that the Committee of Members' Interests has only just begun its work. This arises perhaps from the fact that the Government was aiming to get both Houses in line to start this procedure, which it has been unable to do. The Government welcomes the Opposition's belated decision to nominate members of the Committee. We hope that this decision means that the Committee will now be able to go about its work quickly, smoothly and effectively. I reiterate the Government's firm commitment to the policy of registering members' pecuniary interests. There are elementary but basic principles at stake in this matter. We should not forget those principles, nor should we permit the Opposition to forget or distort them. We all need to work continuously to ensure that the highest standards of probity are upheld in this place. We need to ensure that correct practices are not only followed but also always seen to be followed. We need to guarantee that conflicts do not arise between public duties and private interests. Registering members' pecuniary interests is an essential step in advancing all those goals.

Because of the Opposition's fears and fussing, we will be obliged to give this Committee an extension of time to prepare, endorse and issue the form required for statements of members' interests. That extension will be required for essential practical work, not for another round of tired Opposition objections to the principles at issue, principles which I remind honourable members that Parliament itself has already endorsed. The Government is keen to see rapid progress in this matter, but it is not inclined to hurry the Committee or in any way to pre-empt its important work. The Committee will need to consider, prepare and issue a form. Members will then need to examine the form, complete their statements and return them. Those two steps will need to be done carefully and with due regard to the precedents we will be setting. I therefore propose that we provide 28 days for members to consider and complete their statements of interest after the Committee has sent out the form.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after 'that' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'the Resolution passed by the House of Representatives with respect to a Register of Members' Interest and Forms for completion by the Members of the House in the 34th Parliament be deferred until the Declaration of Registrable Interests is established on a common basis between the Senate and the House of Representatives.'

The reason for moving this amendment is that we believe that for the Special Minister of State and Leader of the House (Mr Young) to come into the House and suggest that honourable members should disclose their pecuniary interests is like a highwayman advising a bank on security measures. He alone of the Ministers, after his return to the Ministry, has failed to have the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) table his new declaration of pecuniary interests. Not only did the last Parliament begin with a farcical exercise with the Prime Minister bringing in a first version of members' interests, but we then had amended members' interests. The Special Minister of State was sacked quite properly and then returned to the Ministry improperly, and the Prime Minister has failed as of this date, so far as I am aware, to have Ministers' declarations tabled in the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —We would love to look at yours, George.

—I am delighted to hear the Minister's interjection. He is very sensitive on matters of judgment about personal behaviour, but there are few who have been so properly condemned by a senior justice of the courts as he has. We all need to remember that it is on national security that this Government is making an absolute mess of things-first, in failing to meet its obligations on MX missile testing, and then in failing to act properly with the New Zealand Government in trying to retain the whole of the ANZUS arrangement. It is this man who has failed in matters affecting national security. It is he who has the hide to come into this House and suggest that members should declare their pecuniary interests.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter should be of great concern to all honourable members in this place. On the last occasion when the resolution to which the motion moved by the Leader of the House refers was before the chamber we on this side of the House first of all canvassed the format of the declaration the Government required. We pointed out the anomalies that were in that form, questioning the extent to which members were required to declare their spouse's financial interests. Not only were they required to declare their spouse's pecuniary interests but also they were required to declare those of their children. We regard that as a total breach of personal privacy. We see no justification whatsoever for members being called upon to act in the way the Government required.

We are concerned about the many anomalies in the declaration form. As has been said on so many occasions in this place, no resolution of this Parliament will impose honesty on those who seek to be dishonest. The sooner honourable members realise that this declaration of pecuniary interests--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I think that this debate has taken place last year.
—Order! There is no substance in that point of order.

— It is important to remember that honourable members on the Government side of the House have far more to hide than anyone else in regard to their involvement in matters outside the Parliament. Even yesterday the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) came in here and said that he would refuse to give indemnity to policemen who could give evidence on matters pertaining to very serious criminal allegations. He is quite prepared to give indemnity to drug runners to disclose criminals but he is not prepared to give it to members of the police force.
—He is part of the Wran cover-up.

—Of course he is. He is part of the Wran cover-up. Looking at this amendment before us today, we must remember that Government members cannot get their act together in this Parliament. What we seek to do, and what my amendment seeks to do, is to suggest that if there is to be any type of register of members' interests it should not be peculiar to the members of the House of Representatives. Even honourable members on the opposite side of the House must ask themselves why senators are not to be asked to make the same disclosures. What is the purpose of requiring a declaration from members of this House when senators, some of whom are Ministers, will apparently be left scot-free?

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from anything else, there is a significant distinction between the obligations of disclosure on the part of those who are Ministers as opposed to those who are ordinary senators or members of the House of Representatives. In the days of the coalition Government we accepted that there needed to be a disclosure of Ministers' interests. Indeed we all provided a declaration, which was periodically updated. That is more than can be said of what has happened in regard to the Ministers of this Government. Our declarations were held by the Secretary to the Prime Minister's Department. It would seem to me that our considering at this stage the motion that the Leader of the House has moved, which suggests that we will receive another 28 days grace, will in no way resolve that fundamental conflict; namely, why senators should be exempt from any disclosure.

This matter has been brought before the House before. I am setting aside all concerns that we have regarding the adequacy and meaningfulness of the required disclosure. These are serious concerns which the Parliament needs to consider and which the new Committee needs to consider. I am sure that the Committee of Members' Interests will look very carefully at the meaningfulness of the form and at the ridiculous way in which the form which the Ministers filled in during the Thirty-third Parliament was set forth.

We need to understand that there are many other people in this place who, if we are to disclose our pecuniary interests, should equally be involved. Are all honourable members opposite saying that members of the Press Gallery ought to be exempt from disclosing their pecuniary interests? They comment on what we do. They have exactly the same involvement. I see the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) sitting in the House. Each member of the Press Gallery has an immediate and vital financial interest in affairs relating to the transfer of media information around Australia. Will members of the Press Gallery in some way be required to disclose their interest in any of the means of communication that are controlled by the Communications ministry before they are allowed to comment on them? That is what is being asked of us. Henceforth, we will be told that we have to fill in a form. It is suggested that if we have an interest in the communications field we will in some way be prejudiced in what we say. One thing that needs to be remembered-I have mentioned that at least the members of the Senate and the House of Representatives should be on common ground-is that there are many others, therefore, who should be considered. If we are to have a declaration of pecuniary interests, I fail to see why such declarations should be restricted to the members of the House of Representatives.

I am concerned that this motion will provide for a 28-days period within which the form will be distributed and members will be required to complete it. I believe that if there is to be a register, the motion is not unreasonable as after the distribution of the form members will have 28 days to complete it, but I see absolutely no justification for it to apply peculiarly to this chamber. If there is to be a form, it must apply equally to the House and to the Senate. I think we need to hear the views of the Committee of Members' Interests as to what other interests are to be disclosed. I think the present form of disclosure should not include references to members' spouses. I see no reason why children should be included in the disclosure. Indeed, I believe it is because they cannot be properly included that the whole farce is before us.

Let me hark back to the attitude that was laid down by the Bowen Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest from which we adopted the proper principles that ensued. Let nobody think that we are not concerned about conflicts of interest, for it is obligatory even under our existing Standing Orders that if any member has a conflict of interest, that is, an area where he has a particular interest as distinct from that of the community at large, he should declare that interest before he speaks and before he votes. We need to understand that in a democratic process, the very fact that a person is elected to the Parliament is of itself a measure of giving him a voice, not for himself alone but for all those he represents. If we deny a person a vote or a voice on matters we do not affect the individual member, we affect all those in his electorate who have a right to expect their voice, attitudes and philosophies to be expressed in this Parliament. The very essence of democracy is that there should be first an understanding that members of the House act with propriety, secondly, that there should be no conflict of interest, but, thirdly that they not be denied a voice. It is for that reason that we believe that the disclosure of pecuniary interests in the form now provided under the Standing Orders and the compliance with it is the preferable basis on which this whole matter should be considered.

It is necessary, however, putting aside all the other intricate arguments about the forms that the original resolution of the Thirty-third Parliament provided, that we now in this Thirty-fourth Parliament start afresh. If there is to be a registration of members' interests, it cannot apply uniquely to this House, it must apply equally to the Senate. It has to be in a form that is acceptable to the members of both chambers. It has to be in a form, therefore, which is not just laid down by a House of Representatives committee in a manner that the motion that the Leader of the House has just submitted would require. It is essential that members of both chambers be subject to exactly the same consequences and responsibilities. After all, we are all answerable to the same Australian electorate. We are all elected members of parliament and there is absolutely no basis in reason or common sense why members of the Senate should not be called on to complete the same type of declaration as that which this motion would seek to require of those who are elected to the House of Representatives. It is with that in mind that I have moved the amendment that we have just introduced into the House which defers the implementation of the whole of the registration procedure until such stage as the Senate has accepted a form which is common to the senators of the Parliament of Australia and members of the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment moved by my colleague the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) because, as I think he has pointed out very clearly today, we are all members of this Parliament. If the Government is fair dinkum about this, it should apply its resolution to all members of the Parliament and not just to the House of Representatives. We should look at the basis of the resolution in the first place. This type of resolution reminds me very much of those adherents of things like Bills of rights, as though the mere statement of a Bill of rights guarantees that those things which the Bill of rights seeks to guarantee, actually occur. If we look at those countries which have a Bill of rights, we will see that many of the freedoms that we cherish in this country, which are supposedly guaranteed by a Bill of rights, are completely set aside. The totalitarian countries of the Left spring first to mind. What has that got to do with a statement of pecuniary interests? If we look at those countries which have a long history of revealing pecuniary interests of members of Congress for various parliaments we will find no greater history of public probity than that of a country such as Australia. The mere fact that these statements are required in no way guarantees that any individual will not seek to circumvent them if he or she is of that disposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I find that there is a great propensity among governments of the Left, socialist governments, to invade personal privacy time after time. Here is another instance of a socialist government in a way attacking personal privacy. I do not think that we as a Federal parliament should allow this to occur. The last Parliament passed a resolution declaring that this was what we must do. When one opposes something like this, those who propose it always use the argument that one has something to hide. That is a lot of nonsense. It is not a question of having anything to hide; it is a question of basic personal liberties. I do not see why our spouses, male or female, should have their personal interests paraded before the people of Australia. Why should our children have their personal interests paraded before the people of Australia merely because we are members of parliament? It is an invasion of their personal privacy, let alone that of members of parliament themselves. I think that the members of the socialist side of politics should think very carefully about what they are seeking to do and what they have, in fact, implemented in this Parliament. There is really no justification for it. If people are crooks they will get around it anyway. If they are not crooks they do not need it. It is as simple as that.

I go back to the point raised by my colleague the right honourable member for New England. If we are to have this declaration of pecuniary interest-we are, because the Parliament has so determined-it is obviously consistent for all members of this Parliament to have to fill in the requisite declaration. I can see that the Leader of the House (Mr Young), who is at the table, is not really giving the Opposition's amendment the consideration that it deserves. If he were a genuine member of parliament, rather than a time server in a socialist government, if he had a feeling for the Parliament as a parliament and for the history of the Parliament as a parliament, he would look at the arguments being advanced by the Opposition which suggest very clearly that all members of this Parliament, be they members of the House of Representatives or the Senate, should be required to undertake exactly the same responsibilities. But no, the Minister grins at his colleagues. That is his usual response when he is required to think.

Matters of principle are at stake in this whole area. The first is whether there should be a requirement. As we know, that issue has already been decided. I opposed it. I still oppose it. I still think that it is wrong. I still think that it is an invasion of personal privacy, not only of members of parliament but more particularly of members of their immediate families. But that question has been dealt with. The second matter of principle is whether this requirement should be directed towards only members of the House of Representatives or all members of the Parliament. The Opposition strongly believes that this requirement should be imposed, if it is to be imposed at all, uniformly on all members of this Parliament, be they members of the House of Representatives or the Senate. It is up to the Government. The Government has not only the responsibility but also the opportunity to impose this requirement upon all members of this Parliament.

I urge very strongly that, rather than rushing hastily into trying to put something on the books which in some way appeases the Government's socialist conscience, it considers the broader, more principled, approach that what applies to members of the House of Representatives should also apply to members of the Senate. This does not move away from an adherence to the requirements imposed by the Parliament on all members of the House of Representatives, but it seeks to impose that requirement on all members of the Parliament. To do so would be consistent; to do so would be logical. I urge the Government to accept the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appeal to the Opposition to withdraw its amendment. I do so not because I necessarily disagree with the sentiments expressed in the amendment but because it is my view that the amendment deals with a matter which will be dealt with by the Committee of Members' Interests. One of the terms of reference of the Committee is to consider what classes of persons, if any, other than members ought to be required to register and declare their interests. We know that any motions passed in this House are passed on party lines and would be considered to be binding on party members. It would seem ridiculous for members of the Committee from either side of the House to take a different point of view later when the Committee deals with these matters. I think it ought be left to the Committee set up by this House to look at the arguments in favour of doing the sort of thing that is proposed in the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable members know, the motion moved by the Leader of the House (Mr Young) proposes a period of 28 days from the time the forms are issued.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you have to report to the Parliament before you issue the forms?

—No, I do not think we necessarily have to do that. The Committee could well come to the conclusion that it should ask the Parliament whether it really insists on members of the House of Representatives being the only ones to be issued with forms. This is quite apart from some of the other problems that arise. I can see many problems arising in respect of the instructions regarding registrable interests. I can see some reason for argument and I can see that some problems will arise. It is obvious that problems have arisen in the past.
—Are you the Chairman?

—Yes. Some problems arose when Ministers were asked to provide something similar to what is now recommended. Of the 27 Ministers at least 14 or 15 admitted to making significant mistakes. I would argue that on top of that they all made at least one other mistake. I refer to the question about whether they have any other interests, such as membership of an organisation where a conflict of interest with a member's public duties could foreseeably arise or be seen to arise. I would argue that it would be ridiculous for any of us not to include membership of a political party. The membership of a political party surely influences our decisions. We all give an undertaking to vote according to the decisions made by the political party to which we belong. I would say that it is extremely difficult for a Minister, whether he be from this side of the House or the other side of the House, to vote against a decision made by a Ministry, a Cabinet or a caucus meeting. If he does, he nearly always resigns.

SPEECH.PARA: I can see arguments in favour of some of the things that happen in respect of such things as sponsored travel and hospitality received. I am thinking of people who go to countries such as Libya, Israel and the Soviet Union and who attend world peace council meetings or meetings of similar sorts of organisations. I think those sorts of things should be registered so that we know whether the kind of hospitality that was extended to them, regardless of whether or not it included Gaddafi watches, could possibly have influenced their point of view. I feel that all these sorts of things can be considered by this Committee. It appears to me to be a committee consisting of seven rational members of this House of Representatives. I do not think we should pre-empt one aspect. It is not as though honourable members have to fill in the forms tomorrow.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you think it should report before that form goes out?

—I think it is up to the Committee to make that decision. I have a feeling that the Committee will raise certain problems in a report before it finally decides that Mr Barlin should issue the forms. That is my view, but it was a very short meeting yesterday and I could be wrong about that.
—I think you should have another one.

—We will have lots of meetings. I can see lots of problems arising before these forms are ready. I do not think we should go overboard now by passing something which could be considered to be binding on people in some way without having had a lengthy discussion at meetings of the Committee and hearing evidence for and against, including evidence from senators. My view is certainly that senators and journalists should be included. I am sure that many journalists are much more influential than any of us.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to withdraw my amendment in light of the assurance of the Chairman of the Committee of Members' Interests. I do not want to interrupt the debate but I believe that if the amendment will in any way inhibit the consideration of the matter by the Committee there might be an advantage in our not proceeding with the amendment, although I in no way withdraw the meaning of the remarks I made a few moments ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Chairman of the Committee of Members' Interests has made a sound point. We withdraw the amendment on the basis that we do not retract anything we said, of course. But, if the Committee is prepared to look at the matter as broadly as the Chairman has suggested, we certainly think that is a good thing to do.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment-by leave-withdrawn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few brief comments. I refer to the manner in which the Leader of the House (Mr Young), who is sitting at the table, actually spoke his speech. With a look of feverish delight he looked across to this side of the chamber and asked: 'What are you hiding?'. I think this is one of the core problems of the matter: This is an act which the Minister supports but which is really not supported by the entire Parliament, either on this side or on the other side. This is a personal vendetta that the Minister is waging against members on this side of the House because of his background and because of the hangups that he developed. He is pursuing members of this chamber yet he is completely dismissing the fact that senators are not being forced at this time to do what he is prescribing for members of this House.

SPEECH.PARA: For the people listening to this debate I will refer to a couple of the aspects of what the Minister has in mind in order to highlight what the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) said about this being an invasion of privacy. If a child of a member of parliament, during the life of the Parliament, is given a second hand push bike which is worth $110 by a grandparent, the member of parliament has to race to the Registrar of Members' Interests to advise him that little Johnnie, who is eight years old, has been given a push bike worth $110. I ask the Minister, every person sitting in the gallery and people listening to the broadcast of this debate whether they feel, as members on this side of the House feel, that we should say to the Minister who is sitting at the table that it is none of his business. There is absolutely no way that a gift such as that will have any influence on the thinking of members in this chamber or in the other chamber when they come to vote. I observe that in the 18 years I have sat in this place I have never seen a member here vote as a result of a pecuniary interest. I have seen members vote as a result of wishing to survive the wrath of a Whip and the wrath of their party but never because of a pecuniary interest.

I sincerely believe that the integrity of members in this place is a lot higher than the impression that the Leader of the House, who is at the table is creating by this move, and I refer to those on the Australian Labor Party side, the National Party of Australia side and the Liberal Party side. I would like examples to be rolled out of where it is felt that a pecuniary interest caused a member to change his vote. I do not believe there is one example, and that goes for the Minister's side of the House as well. The Government is trying to dig into the possessions of wives and children as well as those of members. Surely when the Minister's pecuniary interests are declared some Paddington Bears will be listed and he will probably have to put them under the category of wife's possessions. Frankly, I could not care less-neither could my electorate-how many Paddington Bears he managed to bring into Australia. It has nothing to do with the administration of this nation.

I said that my comments would be short and to the point. I also refer to the fact that if grandparents over the years give, say, $20 a year for each of their grandchildren's birthdays, and it mounts up, the children's savings accounts will have to be declared as a pecuniary interest. A child's account with a local Westpac Banking Corporation or Commonwealth Banking Corporation branch, which contains say $53 or more, according to the Minister at the table has to be declared. I ask the Minister: Is it any wonder that there is so much unrest on both his and my side of the chamber? Many members on his side have spouses in the work force, so from now on every little bit of interest that spouses can make will have to be declared. Heaven forbid, when Australia has to go to these lengths, we will put ourselves on skid row. The Government is creating mistrust in a system when, for a long time, there have been no public suggestions that people have exploited their positions here and had their outside interests as a prime concern.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the Opposition's decision to withdraw its amendment, but I do not welcome the comments of the Opposition members at the beginning of the debate. The instinct of Opposition members is to defend the propertied classes, the gentry, the classes that were for many years legislating in the Parliament for their own interests and not for the people of Australia. That is what the Opposition is doing and that is why our taxation system is in such a quagmire. Opposition members have never paid their taxes. They have protected those who were evading their taxes, and that is what they are trying to do again.
—Why don't you go to Moscow?

—This has nothing to do with Moscow. Honourable members pay their taxes here. The Opposition must not defend tax evaders. That is what we are talking about. Opposition members must not defend only the propertied classes who sent them to Parliament to do that. They must declare their interests. The honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) talked about little Johnnie getting a push bike worth $110, but he did not mention little Johnnie getting a family trust of $1m. How about that? Sir Garfield Barwick was good at family trusts.
—Stop talking about your Treasurer like that.

—The honourable member should shut up. He has been Treasurer. He had better keep quiet. He was in government for seven years and he ruined this country so he had better keep quiet on the Opposition benches. I am a member of the Committee of Members' Interests which will decide the way we will go about this matter. We can go about it in a sensible way. In every democracy it is only rightful to ask whether people have a clash of interests and to be able to establish those interests and verify them. People have to declare their interests. I do not mind being a member of that Committee and ironing out the difficulties in a fair way. We heard from the front runners in the Opposition, such as the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), who said that he had nothing to hide. Of course, two judicial inquiries were held in regard to the matters that he had to hide, so who can believe that he has nothing to hide? Another member of the Opposition, the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), who said that we cannot declare our interests carried into the country in his suitcase something which he would not declare. It was a black and white or colour television set. I question the credentials of members of the Opposition when they talk about a declaration of their interests. I do not mind debating this matter as a member of the Committee or in this House, but I warn honourable members that we will not use the debate to stall the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The question as to whether journalists should declare their interests will be debated, but that is a separate matter. In my opinion they are certainly in a different category. They do not legislate, but they have some influence because they report what members have said. That is sometimes very boring, I admit. But they do not affect legislation and they do not make the decisions. The decisions are made by the Parliament and I think the interests of members should be declared so that the public-the voters, the people of Australia-can see that there is no clash of interests as to whether members hold directorships, for instance, or properties, or whether they have not taken into account a million dollar investment in rural properties when they are fighting for rural subsidies. We want to be able to establish whether there is a clash of interest in that regard. The only way to establish that is for members to declare their interests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the purpose of the declaration that we are to make is to get on the record some kind of conflict of interest, it is as misconceived as the detail is incompetent. One needs only to look at it to see that some of the matters that are meant to be dealt with by declaration can have nothing to do with the work that we are meant to be doing in this place and are no more than a straightforward invasion of privacy. Let us look at some of the items dreamed up by the dunderheads on the other side of the House. One item is partnerships indicating the nature of the interest. Presumably, it is an interest in a partnership; it cannot be anything else. The activities of the partnership and the total amount of assets and liabilities-what relevance does the total amount of assets and liabilities have? It will certainly tell anybody who is interested in finding out whether a member is a good prospect to be knocked off and what is his worth. However, it has nothing to do with anything that a member does in this House. It cannot conceivably raise any question of conflict of interest.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at another item-liabilities, excluding short term credit arrangements. If liabilities, are to be included why should we exclude short term credit arrangements? If we are looking for somebody who is experiencing difficulties, the short term credit arrangement-if it is included- will tell us a great deal more than the long term credit arrangement. Apparently, that is to be kept out. I wonder whether any members on the other side of the House have any short term credit arrangements which would be of some embarrassment if they were to reach the light of day. Anyway, they are not to be included. Members have to indicate the nature of any long term credit arrangements and the creditor concerned.

Another item concerns savings or investment accounts. There must be a million or so savings accounts in this country. What possible relevance has that to any work that we do in this place? It has none. The same thing applies in relation to investment accounts. If a member has a savings account, he must not only say that he has it, but also indicate the nature and name of the bank or other institution concerned. Again, that will tell people in the criminal sector of our country just how one stands. That, it can be said, is a thief's charter.

Another matter concerns the nature of any other assets, including collections. Is that not brilliant? We all know that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has a collection, of antique French clocks, I think, and he is on the record as saying proudly that he is a much better collector than any Tory. If we really want to keep the housebreakers of this country advised about things, let us state the nature of any collection and tell them where the collection is to be found so they can come in and knock us over.

If we are going to have a declaration of interests of members of this House it is only sensible, as the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) pointed out, that the declaration of interests should be common to both Houses. It should be common in form and should be entered into at the same time. It is nonsense to operate on the assumption that in some way the interests of members of one House should be made public but the interests of members of another House should not be; each House having co-equal powers, save with certain exceptions.

The last point to make is that if this Committee of Members' Interests is to do any sensible work-if we are to have this invasion of privacy perpetrated upon us-when it sits it should ask itself the question: What is meant by a conflict of interest? The next question it should ask itself is: What interests are likely to give rise or may possibly give rise to a conflict between interest and duty? They should put to one side some of those matters which I have referred to as irrelevant, dangerous and a gross and unwarranted invasion of privacy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned that the withdrawal of the amendment moved by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) will mean that we will now be voting specifically for the latter parts of the motion moved by the Leader of the House (Mr Young), which adopt the procedures set out previously by the parental resolution concerning this matter of pecuniary interests. I do not believe that if the Senate, also under Australian Labor Party direction, also introduces this measure that will make the measure any more proper or right than we believed it to be when we opposed it in this House on the first occasion it was debated here. I would have supported the amendment of the Leader of the National Party on the basis that it was some form of protest. I believe it is best that we as a House put off the operation of this proposal to a time far removed from the present, to a time when we can further consider the full ramifications.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite obviously ridiculous that a Minister of this Government who so offended the security of this nation by leaking information in a car park in this city that he was warned by a judge and by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) should have transgressed again and should have been subjected to further inquiry about a different matter of probity in relation to the operation of his ministerial responsibilities. If he did not learn the first time, I put it to the House, what would he have learned the second time? What, therefore, in what is proposed here, would prevent him from doing something further? I believe that the declaration of that Minister's pecuniary interests will do nothing to lift his desire to fulfil properly his responsibilities to the Australian community.

We can distil this to the point of absurdity. Why is every elector, who has the first and primary responsibility of deciding this country's future, not required to make some sort of pecuniary interest declaration? If members are so to declare their interests, what about the persons who have the first and primary responsibility? Of course, that reduces the whole proposition to an absolute nonsense and farce. In any event, the Leader of the National Party has again fully canvassed the reasons why we ought not to be involved in this at all. I believe that in now supporting the motion of the Leader of the House we are beginning to support all the arrangements which we objected to so vigorously previously. On that basis, and without taking further time of the House, I move as an amendment:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'the operation of the resolution adopted by the House on 9 October 1984, a.m. relating to the registration and declaration of Members' Interests be deferred until the commencement of the 35th Parliament'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment, Madam Deputy Speaker, and in so doing I demonstrate my support of the words expressed by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) when he identified the complete and utter ridiculousness of the situation that the motion moved by the Leader of the House (Mr Young) and the original resolution would impose. At one stage I thought that for the first time in my married life I would find out how much money my wife had in her bank accounts. She has always failed to tell me. However, on my telling her that this matter was coming forward again she told me that I still am not going to find out because she is not going to be part of that declaration. I assure honourable members that the money which she has managed to save throughout our married life and has in a few bank accounts is not going to affect any decision which I take in this place. The simple and very good reason for that is that we trust each other and I know that she would not try to influence anything that I did in this place. That is just by the way.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us get down to some of the serious matters members of the Government have left out of their silly motion. We all know that our bank accounts do not affect our decisions in this place. We all know those sorts of things. We all know, for example, that the value of our homes has little effect in this regard. We all know that if we are concerned about mortgage interest rates it is on behalf of our constituents that we are concerned and not on behalf of ourselves. We know that that is so for very good reasons. If we want to get down to it, one good reason is that we want to keep our positions in this place. But what has the Government left out again? What about rich and powerful friends? Do not let honourable members opposite tell me that rich and powerful friends cannot have influence. Of course, they have influence. Yesterday we heard the Government's moralistic Treasurer (Mr Keating) worrying about the casino situation in the Northern Territory.
Government members-So he should.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, so he should. I am glad to hear honourable members opposite say that. Some Labor members of Parliament in Queensland were very moralistic about a certain Robert J. L. Hawke running around trying to get the casino licence up there for Eddie Kornhauser.
—Order! The honourable member will refer to the Prime Minister as the Prime Minister.
—Madam Deputy Speaker, he was not the Prime Minister when he was running around up there; he was the honourable member for Wills.
—Order! The honourable member will heed the Chair.

—I am happy to repeat that the honourable member for Wills was running around Queensland trying to get a casino licence for Eddie Kornhauser, a close friend. Is that a matter of influence? Of course it is a matter of influence. It is a matter of public record-we can read it in the Blanche D'Alpuget book-that certain very big people used to run around and take him for rides in their Rolls Royces and give him the keys to drive their cars. Now he is one of those who has to take a decision on whether Ansett Airlines of Australia is allowed to compete with Qantas Airways Ltd. I have a funny feeling that his mind is small enough to be influenced sufficiently by that Rolls Royce to give that particular gentleman a chance. Is that a conflict of interest? Why is that interest not being declared? That is absolute stupidity. We know the Prime Minister never has to worry too much about his bank accounts because he carries it all in his brief case. Why do we not have to declare what we keep in our brief cases? What about that? No, we do not have to declare that. Why do we not have to declare how much foreign currency we get? What about identifying our traveller's cheques? After all, that would be pretty simple. Why do we not have to do that?

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at this matter in all seriousness. Let us look at the fact that the Senate is not going to do anything about this. I repeat, the Senate is not going to do anything about this. The Government wants to impose a situation on the Opposition, which it will prove in a few minutes has no power to make decisions in this place. Yet the Government accepts that there will be no such constraints on senators, who individually can roll the Government's legislation any time they wish. That is silly, is it not? Yet honourable members opposite will go along with that.

Knowing how Government members will vote in a few minutes, let us accept that we should give a bit of advice to the Committee of Members' Interests. I sincerely hope that when the Committee gets its priorities into place it will realise that it has a responsibility to investigate first those members who have the greatest opportunity to influence this country-the Ministers, starting with the Prime Minister. I am quite happy to give the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) a bit of advice if he gets lost investigating the Prime Minister. We have a bit of evidence for him. When the Committee finishes with the Prime Minister I suggest that it starts on the Treasurer. I think it is reasonable for the Treasurer, in the declaration of his pecuniary interests, to declare how a clerk working for a union can, after 16 years in this place on the penurious salary that is paid in this place, accumulate millions of dollars. That might be an interesting inquiry. I am not exactly sure to what extent it would become a conflict of interests. I merely put to the House that the Treasurer is a very wealthy man and I do not know how he has achieved that wealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for O'Connor is getting close to impugning members' motives.

—I will say no more on that matter, Madam Chair. These are some of the issues. I would be very concerned if the Committee were to ask special questions of any member of the House, any back bencher, unless it would assure us that it had adequately inquired into those who take the big decisions and who deal with the big bickies, where influence and conflict of interest really count. The back benchers of this place are the area of government most removed from the problems of conflict of interest. It starts down in local government. We happen to know that in New South Wales the conflict of interest resides with power brokers there. It is they who make or break councillors, but it is councillors who take decisions on development.
—Not at Carnarvon.

—I was talking about New South Wales where the honourable member's Party in particular has badly corrupted the local government scene. The reality is that they are matters for conflict. Senior party officials are not to be included in the motion, but only back benchers who are so distanced from the situation.
—Read today's Herald.
—About the police and Wran's cover-up, do you mean?

—We know a little about those situations, but I am more interested in the type of actions the Committee might take. It might ask for a little more information than the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) gave us about Coomel Pty Ltd. We had to dig that out. What a surprise arose out of that. At what stage will a Minister be influenced in his decisions on tax when he has made some rather peculiar ones himself? Let us get back to the point. If Government members want this type of motion, let them be dinkum about it. Let them guarantee to the Australian people that they are all clean, because that is where it should start. Before Government members get into these sorts of areas, they should stop and think about a declaration of past activities that might give some person great influence.
—What about yours?

—I am quite happy. Mine are all out in the arena. Nobody influences me. Nobody has been able to frighten me in my lifetime, and the blokes opposite have learned that. The Minister for Trade thought he was going to put me down, and if the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Keogh) wants me to start on him, I will take my time and do it. He should keep quiet. He does not know what he is talking about. He has not the power of sitting in the chair at the moment. It is my turn, so be quiet.
—Order! I remind the honourable member for O'Connor that it is the Chair which decides who will be quiet.

—Thank you, Madam Chair. I will rely on your protection in the future. Let us think about people who have taken actions that may allow pressure to be applied to them so that there is conflict with their interests. There are activities that I can bring to the attention of the House very quickly. The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) might consider that position when he is addressing his information to the Committee. There are plenty of others. I sincerely hope that everybody in declaring his pecuniary interests does not forget one little thing: It seems peculiar, and I do not know why, but mail keeps coming to me and I am anxious to assist the Committee in its inquiries.
—And you won't charge for it, will you?

—I will not charge a penny, and I will volunteer it with goodwill. I think I have made my point that this is a foolish motion. The obvious solution is that which has been proposed by the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall)-withdraw the motion. Because people work slowly in these matters and minds take a little while to understand, a period of three years should be given for the Committee to write a sensible pecuniary interests proposition, if at the end of that period the Government thinks it worth while. It is governments that must answer to the people; it is governments that must be squeaky clean. All those in government should make sure that they are squeaky clean before they move to this side of the House to muck around. Unfortunately, the Opposition has not yet got the power to influence the decisions of this Government. People in the Senate do, but the Government does not intend to ask senators to do anything because it cannot stand over them. The reality is that it is the Government's responsibility now, it is in the Government's hands, and the Government must wear it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: — It is interesting to note that the House is hearing from the other side a recycling of arguments that have been put to this Parliament for the last 12 years. Nothing changes. Having heard the honourable member for O'Connor speak on this issue I would inform him that of over 600 members the only person in the House of Commons who opposed the introduction of the tabling of details of members' pecuniary interests was Enoch Powell. So there has to be something similar running through their veins here. One had the feeling that at Thredbo the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) must have been drinking petrol, judging by the way he spoke about this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall), the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) and the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) took the opportunity to bring me under some personal attack to try to camouflage this issue. Can one imagine, with all the tactics the Opposition can adopt, three worse people being put up? Should the right honourable member for New England point the finger at anybody in Australia about somebody being a crook? For God's sake, $500,000 went missing out of the family funds and no one knew where it went.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker, I ask that the Minister withdraw that imputation. It is neither correct, nor is it the sort of remark that should be made.
—Order! The Leader of the House will withdraw.

—I withdraw. The fact is that the right honourable member for New England has been highlighted over a number of years for his activities and yet he stands before this House and says 'This is terrible', that I am personally involved and that this is crook because I am putting it forward. He is a great man of the people and will stand up for their rights. It is the same thing Opposition members have been saying for 12 years in trying to prevent proper practice in this House. The honourable member for Boothby says that this matter should be put off for another three years because it has not been looked at. I remind the honourable member for Boothby that the right honourable member for New England and several of his colleagues-the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), the former member for Braddon (Mr Groom), and others-were for the last two years on the committee that brought down this recommendation. We made several changes in the motion based on the propositions put to the Committee by Opposition members. It is not as if this motion comes before this House not having been considered.
—On a point of order, I remind the Minister that, although some of us sat on that committee, we submitted a dissenting report. He should mention that to complete the story.
—Order! No point of order is involved.

—In the final analysis when they were asked to vote on it, they said that they did not want it because that is the traditional conservative party attitude on this issue. I am saying that the motion encompasses some changes as a result of suggestions put forward to the Committee by Opposition members. We did not just come in here and say 'This is the way it will be' when we put the motion down on 9 October 1984. It does encompass some of the views which honourable members opposite put forward on behalf of their parties. They know the intent of the Parliament. The resolution was carried in 1983. It took almost two years for the Standing Orders Committee to look at it. The great argument from the other side seems to be that if we are not going to do something in the Senate, we should not do it in the House of Representatives. I ask honourable members opposite to understand and accept that the House of Representatives has the government of Australia. The Senate may want to sit around, as it seems to do. The Senate has had this issue before it for a couple of years, and it has not even been put on the agenda. The House of Representatives has the government of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Moreton says that someone will have to worry about his eight-year old son getting a $100 bike. As the honourable member received three hundred thousand bucks out of the parliamentary superannuation fund, I would not have thought that he would have been so lousy. I would have thought he would have bought his son a decent bike, registered it and shown himself for what he is; namely, a kind hearted, generous person who got three hundred thousand bucks out of the superannuation scheme. We just hope that the honourable member invests it wisely and shows us that he has the potential to sit on the front bench. For God's sake, these are some of the arguments the Opposition uses against what we are trying to do!

What the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) says is right. We laid down the guidelines in the resolution of 9 October. We have now extended the time for compliance. It may well be that the Committee of Members' Interests will come to the Government and say that there are certain proposals it wants to put before Parliament in relation to the operation of this resolution. The Government will look at those proposals and the Parliament can debate the matter again. But there can be no diverting from the Government's intention that this practice will be carried out for members of the House of Representatives. We have been saying that since 1973.

The right honourable member for New England said that this procedure is practised within the present Ministry, as it was with previous Government's Ministry. The only difference is that we have said that all members of parliament should comply, and not just Ministers. That is the way it will be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is your's, Mick? Why did the Prime Minister not table yours?
— Order! The Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting.
—It is quite okay, Madam Deputy Speaker, because my pecuniary interests were given to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in exactly the same way as were other Ministers'.
—You did not table them.

—They were not tabled because I did not happen to be in the Ministry when the declarations were tabled. All honourable members opposite have to fathom out is that no more declarations have since been tabled.
—Are you not going to table the Customs form this time?

—I can tell the right honourable member for New England that if he wants to swap his declaration with mine, his will make a lot more interesting reading than will mine. If the right honourable member wants to swap comic books--
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I invite the Minister to table the form now.
—There is no point of order; that is quite frivolous.

—My declaration will be tabled in compliance with the rules applying to all other Ministers. It will be done in exactly the same way and at exactly the same time. I can assure the honourable member that it will not prove all that interesting.
—As an expert on forms, will you help the new members in filling in their forms?

—Yes, I certainly will. I say to the honourable member that my advice on forms would be better than his advice on horses. If new members want a little more advice I can advise them not to use the same vaseline that the honourable member uses. The Government will continue in the way in which it intended it should continue when it gave notice of this matter in 1983. Over the last two years the Standing Orders Committee has done an enormous amount of work on this matter. If the Committee comes back to Parliament with further suggestions they will be looked at. I move:

Question resolved in the affirmative.

That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Steele Hall's amendment) stand part of the question.
